awd_titl_txt: Core Support for the National Academy of Sciences' Board on Chemical Sciences and Technology (BCST) and Chemical Sciences Roundtable (CSR)
awd_abstract_narration:
With the support of the Divisions of Chemistry (CHE) and Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental and Transport Systems (CBET), Jeremy Mathis and Maggie Walser of the National Academy of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine guide the management of the core activities of both the Board on Chemical Sciences and Technology (BCST) and the Chemical Sciences Roundtable (CSR). The results of BCST and CSR discussions and workshops are disseminated through workshop reports made available through professional societies, scientific and trade publications, and on the web.

The BCST has broad representation from academe and industry and uses its collective expertise to identify the needs of the community. The BCST provides peer-reviewed consensus reports, workshops, and symposia. The BCST enhances the impacts of the chemistry and chemical engineering communities by engaging in questions of importance to federal decision-makers. BCST members oversee a portfolio of ad hoc studies in key areas of education, workforce, and research issues. Specific areas of consideration for this funding period include: the quantum information revolution, the green economy, materials sciences and its application to fields such as heat transfer, electrochemistry related to battery technology, single cell/molecule measurements, data sciences, undergraduate education and workforce development, sensor miniaturization and improvements, and laboratory automation. By raising issues impacting the conduct of chemistry and chemical engineering research with federal officials, BCST helps assure that the community of practitioners can remain at the forefront of knowledge. The CSR provides an apolitical forum for leaders in the chemical sciences and engineering, with the objective of enhancing understanding of issues that affect government, academic, national laboratory, and nonprofit sectors. CSR discussions provide a vehicle for interaction among the participants. These participants discuss and report on education, exchange of information, and issues and trends that affect the chemical sciences. CSR engages leading scientists and engineers to identify and explore, through workshops, emerging topics of importance to the chemical community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

The Board on Chemical Sciences and Technology (BCST) is the focal point within the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine for chemical sciences and engineering. The board works in eight strategic areas: basic research; chemical and energy industries; biochemistry; environmental chemistry; pharmaceutical chemistry; electrochemistry; national security; and education and workforce development. The board explores the science, policies, and infrastructure needed to support the vitality of the chemical and chemical engineering disciplines and their impacts on society. The board exercises leadership within the chemical sciences and engineering communities by helping to identify and communicate the needs for these fields, responds to specific requests for advice and information from government agencies and Congress, and oversees a variety of study projects related to the chemical sciences and engineering. Because chemistry is essential to a broad range of issues, the board provides guidance to many different agencies, including a longstanding engagement with the NSF’s Division of Chemistry and Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental and Transport Systems as well as a long-established professional relationship with the Department of Energy’s Basic Energy Sciences program.

The mission of the Chemical Sciences Roundtable (CSR), an ongoing activity of the BCST, is to provide a science-oriented, apolitical forum to discuss and enhance understanding of the critical issues in chemical science and technology affecting the government, industrial, and academic sectors. It is not a source of advice for federal agencies, but an educational vehicle for exchange of information that could lead to follow-up action by participants and their parent organizations. CSR plans and hosts one workshop annually on a topic deemed particularly important to the chemical sciences community, for which summaries are published, but no recommendations are made. Additionally, the CSR hosts three webinars per calendar year to bring attention to and start conversations around topics of importance.

The BCST held six two-day business meetings from 09/01/2021 - 08/31/2024, where the appointed members of the board discussed the ongoing activities overseen by BCST and to hear from invited speakers, including federal officials, industry representatives, and academic researchers, on potential topics of interest for future activities. During this period, the following consensus studies and proceedings were completed by BCST, either led by or in collaboration with other boards, and are available free for download at www.nap.edu:

  • Carbon Utilization Infrastructure, Markets, and Research and Development: A Final Report (2024)
  • A Research Agenda Toward Atmospheric Methane Removal (2024)
  • Chemical Terrorism: Assessment of U.S. Strategies in the Era of Great Power Competition (2024)
  • Advancing Chemistry and Quantum Information Science: An Assessment of Research Opportunities at the Interface of Chemistry and Quantum Information Science in the United States (2023)
  • Recycled Plastics in Infrastructure: Current Practices, Understanding, and Opportunities (2023)
  • Carbon Dioxide Utilization Markets and Infrastructure: Status and Opportunities: A First Report (2023)
  • Management of Indoor Air and Airborne Pathogens: Proceedings of a Workshop Series–in Brief (2023)
  • Innovations in Catalysis to Address Modern Challenges: Proceedings of a Workshop–in Brief (2023)
  • The Importance of Chemical Research to the U.S. Economy (2022)
  • Why Indoor Chemistry Matters (2022)
  • The Chemistry of Fires at the Wildland-Urban Interface (2022)
  • New Directions for Chemical Engineering (2022)
  • Empowering Tomorrow's Chemist: Laboratory Automation and Accelerated Synthesis: Proceedings of a Workshop–in Brief (2022)
  • Wildland Fires: Toward Improved Understanding and Forecasting of Air Quality Impacts: Proceedings of a Workshop (2022)
  • Innovations in Pharmaceutical Manufacturing on the Horizon: Proceedings of a Workshop–in Brief (2022)

The CSR held six business meetings from 09/01/2021 - 08/31/2024 to discuss and determine the topics for the webinars and workshops. During this period, the roundtable hosted three 1.5-day workshops and eight 1.5-hour webinars (listed below). Proceedings in brief are published following each workshop and are available free download at www.nap.edu.

Workshops:

  • Future Implications of Open Access and FAIR Data Practices on Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Publications (2024)
  • Innovations in Catalysis to Address Modern Challenges (2022)
  • Laboratory Automation and Accelerated Synthesis: Empowering Tomorrow’s Chemist (2021)

Webinars:

  • AI + Sustainable Chemistry (2024)
  • Open Access and FAIR Data in the Chemical Sciences (2023)
  • Chemistry and Food: Safety, Authenticity, and Other Challenges (2023)
  • Sustainable Recycling of Critical Materials in Lithium-Ion Batteries (2023)
  • Examining Challenges in Scaling Hydrogen Energy (2022)
  • Emerging Development of Biopolymer Synthesis (2022)
  • Advancing Agricultural Herbicides through Chemistry (2022)
  • Future Directions of Sustainability in Chemical Manufacturing (2021)

BCST and CSR provide access to information on all of their activities through their respective websites, https://www.nationalacademies.org/bcst/board-on-chemical-sciences-and-technology and https://www.nationalacademies.org/our-work/chemical-sciences-roundtable. A dissemination plan and outreach strategy are developed for every report and workshop summary. Using the BCST and CSR communications associate in addition to the communications team at the National Academies, our publications are disseminated using a variety of channels. All newsletters, posts, and communications are tailored for their individualized platforms to provide the most effective and impactful dissemination of our studies and events.
